awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Showups vs. Lineups: A Comparison of Two Identification Techniques
awd_abstract_narration:
In the area of eyewitness identification, few studies compare showups (one-person identifications), simultaneous lineups (all lineup members viewed simultaneously), and sequential lineups (lineup members viewed one at a time) to determine which is most accurate. The current research involves a series of experiments in which participants will first watch a staged video of multiple perpetrators breaking into a storage unit and then complete a showup, sequential lineup, and simultaneous lineup, each involving a different suspect. Finally, participants will indicate their confidence in their decision and complete additional questions about the manipulation and witnessing experience. The current research has three objectives: to compare identification accuracy between showups and lineups within a single set of studies; to develop techniques that improve eyewitness identification; and to promote a better understanding of the underlying memory and decision-making processes that occur in showup and lineup identifications using formal computational models. 

The research focuses on improving eyewitness identification in showups and reducing the fallibility of eyewitness evidence leading to the wrongful conviction of the innocent.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The U.S. Supreme Court, state courts, and social science researchers stated that showup identifications (one-person identifications) were less reliable than lineup identifications. Moreover, 74% of eyewitness experts endorsed false identifications as more likely to occur from showups than lineups. Although showups appeared to be less reliable, existing research provided mixed support for this view (Goodsell, Wetmore, Neuschatz, & Gronlund, 2013). Therefore, we set out to compare identification accuracy between showups and lineups within a single set of studies to determine if showups really were less accurate.

            In our first study, Gronlund et al., 2012, we utilized data from Gronlund et al. (2009) that compared simultaneous (all members shown at once) and sequential (members shown one at a time) lineup formats, and added a comparable showup condition. Results showed that showups were always inferior to lineups. We next set out to investigate two sets of circumstances where the use of showups might be favored over lineups: (1) the presence of matching clothing, and (2) shorter retention interval and unfair lineup.

            First, because showups can be conducted relatively quickly after a crime occurs, it may be the case that witnesses can use clothing as a cue to aid their decision making from showups. Although prior research suggested that clothing match would only raise the risk to an innocent suspect, our examination (Wetmore et al., 2015a) found that witnesses were better able to differentiate between guilty and innocent suspects when there was a clothing match from the crime to showup identification.

            Secondly, showups conducted quickly may have an advantage over lineups because lineups are typically conducted long after the crime occurs. However, showups could still be at a disadvantage because showups contain no fillers (known innocent lineup members) to protect against a witness who is too willing to make a choice. In Wetmore et al. (2015b), we conducted a study comparing showups to lineups containing either good fillers (matching the description of the perpetrator) or poor fillers, where witnesses were being testing immediately (five minutes after viewing a mock crime) or two days later. Results showed that lineups were always better – even when comparing showups conducted immediately to lineups with poor fillers conducted two days later.

            Finally, we conducted an examination of the extant literature, including the studies we conducted, resulting in over 7500 participants, which confirmed that showups are an inferior procedure to lineups. The data also revealed that confidence was better calibrated to accuracy for lineups than for showups. That is, witnesses expressing high confidence tended to be more accurate when making decisions from lineups than showups (and likewise, witnesses expressing low confidence are more likely to have NOT chosen the guilty suspect from a lineup than a showup).

            Lastly, we utilized a computational memory model (Clark, 2003) designed for eyewitness identification to explore these findings. As originally conceived, the model incorrectly predicted similar levels of performance across lineups and showups. However, our data showed that simultaneous lineups were superior to sequential lineups and showups, although placing the suspect later (e.g., position 5 or 6) in the sequential lineup sometimes resulted in improved performance. Therefore, we implemented an idea in the model that parti...
por.por_txt_cntn:
The U.S. Supreme Court, state courts, and social science researchers stated that showup identifications (one-person identifications) were less reliable than lineup identifications. Moreover, 74% of eyewitness experts endorsed false identifications as more likely to occur from showups than lineups. Although showups appeared to be less reliable, existing research provided mixed support for this view (Goodsell, Wetmore, Neuschatz, & Gronlund, 2013). Therefore, we set out to compare identification accuracy between showups and lineups within a single set of studies to determine if showups really were less accurate.

            In our first study, Gronlund et al., 2012, we utilized data from Gronlund et al. (2009) that compared simultaneous (all members shown at once) and sequential (members shown one at a time) lineup formats, and added a comparable showup condition. Results showed that showups were always inferior to lineups. We next set out to investigate two sets of circumstances where the use of showups might be favored over lineups: (1) the presence of matching clothing, and (2) shorter retention interval and unfair lineup.

            First, because showups can be conducted relatively quickly after a crime occurs, it may be the case that witnesses can use clothing as a cue to aid their decision making from showups. Although prior research suggested that clothing match would only raise the risk to an innocent suspect, our examination (Wetmore et al., 2015a) found that witnesses were better able to differentiate between guilty and innocent suspects when there was a clothing match from the crime to showup identification.

            Secondly, showups conducted quickly may have an advantage over lineups because lineups are typically conducted long after the crime occurs. However, showups could still be at a disadvantage because showups contain no fillers (known innocent lineup members) to protect against a witness who is too willing to make a choice. In Wetmore et al. (2015b), we conducted a study comparing showups to lineups containing either good fillers (matching the description of the perpetrator) or poor fillers, where witnesses were being testing immediately (five minutes after viewing a mock crime) or two days later. Results showed that lineups were always better – even when comparing showups conducted immediately to lineups with poor fillers conducted two days later.

            Finally, we conducted an examination of the extant literature, including the studies we conducted, resulting in over 7500 participants, which confirmed that showups are an inferior procedure to lineups. The data also revealed that confidence was better calibrated to accuracy for lineups than for showups. That is, witnesses expressing high confidence tended to be more accurate when making decisions from lineups than showups (and likewise, witnesses expressing low confidence are more likely to have NOT chosen the guilty suspect from a lineup than a showup).

            Lastly, we utilized a computational memory model (Clark, 2003) designed for eyewitness identification to explore these findings. As originally conceived, the model incorrectly predicted similar levels of performance across lineups and showups. However, our data showed that simultaneous lineups were superior to sequential lineups and showups, although placing the suspect later (e.g., position 5 or 6) in the sequential lineup sometimes resulted in improved performance. Therefore, we implemented an idea in the model that participants could learn to distinguish which features are useful to making a memory decision as the sequential lineup unfolds. However, witnesses are unable to do this in a showup due to the lack of fillers/alternatives. This idea resulted in a closer correspondence of the model predictions to the observed data, but still incorrectly predicted showup performance to be better than the observed data.
